The life expectancy of people with Down syndrome has increased significantly, with some individuals living into their 60s and 70s. watermarked_text: machines are thought to work in two ways : On a high pulse rate of 90 - 130 Hz ( the normal method of use ), the electrical impulses delivered directly to the underlying perineum muscle produce a quick, reflexlike muscle contraction. This method stimulates the muscle to contract in a jerky fashion, typically producing quick, short contractions of the perineum, vulva ( labia ), urethra, and anal sphincter. The second way these machines are reputed to work is on a lower pulse rate, 13 - 26 Hz in particular. At this pulse rate, the electrical nerve current is said to induce a sustained muscle contraction. The prolonged contractions supposedly allow for greater blood flow and increase the sensitivity of the stimulated area ( Hodge, 1976, pp. 29, 35 ). The Kegel machine, however, cannot be located for hands - on inspection or accurate assessment of its claimed features and effects. Clinical experiences and opinions, as gathered from health professionals, reveal mixed views on the Kegel device. Some believe that such a device can indeed provide some benefit for certain individuals
unwatermarked_text:
machines are thought to work in two ways : On a high pulse rate of 90 - 130 Hz ( the normal method of use ), the electrical impulses stimulate the muscles and nerves.
There are various types & sizes of TENS machines available. The most common type is a battery - powered unit. Some have multiple channels which allow for the use of several pairs of electrodes simultaneously, whilst others have single channel devices.
The electrodes are usually made of a conductive rubber or gel-filled material and are placed on the skin in the area to be treated. The machine is adjusted so that the intensity of the electrical pulses is comfortable but not painful. The duration of treatment depends on the condition being treated, but typically 15 - 30 minutes is sufficient. Treatments can be carried out daily for as long as needed.
While TENS is generally safe and well - tolerated when used as directed, there are some contraindications. These include :
1. Implants such as pacemakers, ICDs, or neurostimulators.
2. Severe infections or inflammatory skin conditions.
3. Presence of implanted electrodes or metal fragments near the treatment site
natural_text: generated by the TENS machine interfere with and block pain messages sent to the brain . This is due to the gate control theory of pain . This proposes that there is a gate mechanism in the brain and spinal cord nerves ( the central nervous system ) . When the gate is open , pain messages get through to the brain and we feel pain . When the gate is closed , these pain messages are blocked and we do not feel pain . TENS machines are thought to stimulate certain non - pain - carrying nerves and close the gate . In effect , the brain is busy dealing with the messages it receives quickly from the TENS machine , rather than the slower ( more painful ) pain signals that the body is receiving from elsewhere . It explains why , if you injure yourself , rubbing that area can temporarily reduce the pain . When the machine is set on a low pulse rate ( 2 - 5 Hz ) it stimulates the body to make its own pain - easing chemicals called endorphins . These act a bit like morphine to block pain signals .,

Children with dyspraxia may therefore tend to be untidy in their work or have difficulty drawing and painting, and may also struggle with tasks such as cutting out shapes, tying knots or riding a bike. The movement difficulties often cause frustration and can impact on self-esteem and confidence.
Children with dyspraxis often have difficulty with co-ordinating specific muscle groups, which makes skills such as tying shoelaces, fastening buttons and using zips (known as fast and fine motor skills ) challenging for them. They may also experience difficulties when they are required to use their non-preferred (non-dominant) hand, as this can be harder for them than tasks using their dominant hand. These difficulties may also extend to playing sports, where spatial awareness and coordination are important.
Dyspraxia affects the planning and execution of movements, and can impact significantly on everyday living skills and quality of life. However, once identified, appropriate support and intervention can greatly improve the child's ability to manage their daily tasks and activities, and help to enhance their self-esteem

Delays in motor milestones : Your child may have difficulty with movement skills such as crawling, walking, or even tying their shoes.
Discoordinated movements : Your child might have trouble with things like stacking blocks, buttoning a shirt, or using a fork and knife. Their movements may appear awkward or jerky.
Difficulty with writing and fine motor skills : Your child likely has poor handwriting and may struggle with activities like drawing, coloring, or using scissors.

Learning a new skill requires perseverance and practice. Every time we perform the skill, connections between our nerves are strengthened, making it easier to perform the action the next time. With enough practice, our nerve connections become very good at this particular task, and the skill becomes a habit or automatic response. This is why it often takes a long time to learn complex skills like playing a musical instrument or riding a bicycle. Our nervous system has to make many connections to coordinate all the different parts involved in these activities.
Sometimes, our nervous system may not form the connections we need to learn a skill quickly or easily. This can be due to various factors, including genes, injury, or lack of practice. to predict the outcome of the next general election. The truth is that unless the question is asked in exactly the same way, different surveys will give different results. The only survey that would give the same result is one asked with a mirror - held up to one particular party’s face. To give the impression that different surveys are being used to predict the same outcome is a bit like holding a mirror up to your face and pretending the reflection is someone else.
There is an important principle in polling called the'margin of error '. This is essentially a measure of how confident we can be that the result obtained is accurate. In simple terms, if the margin of error is plus or minus 3%, then the true result could be 3% above or 3% below the result obtained in the survey. Some surveys have lower margins of error than others, depending on factors such as sample size and how good their sampling method is. So, even if two surveys are asking the same question, their results can differ simply due to the natural variation in responses that the margin of errors allow for.
It is also worth noting that there are various ways to ask

It is not a measure of the actual popularity of the parties or of the likely outcome of the general election. 1.7

Is genetic testing for Huntington's disease accurate?
Genetic testing for Huntington's disease is accurate in identifying carriers of the mutation, but it has some limitations. The test can accurately diagnose individuals with HD if they have a family history of the disease and are showing symptoms consistent with it. However, in some cases, genetic testing may give inconclusive or uncertain results. This can occur due to certain factors such as a genetic variant that is only present in a small percentage of HD cases or genetic variations that can affect the accuracy of the test. In these cases, further testing or consultation with a genetic specialist may be necessary to determine the likelihood of having HD.

It's a bleed inside the skull, where there's a space between the skull and the outer covering of the brain. You can have a bleed on one side or the other. It usually happens because of an injury to the skull, like a punch or a fall. The bleed can put pressure on the brain, which can cause it to swell and bruise. The extradural haemotoma results from a bleed into the potential space between the inner surface of the skull and its outer covering. The bleeding usually occurs due to a head injury that
natural_text: most commonly after a fractured skull caused by a head injury . The fractured skull bone can cause separation of the dura mater from the inside of the skull and can cause damage to a blood vessel ( usually an artery ) . The damaged blood vessel causes blood to leak and collect in the potential epidural space between the skull and the dura mater . This build - up of blood can cause the pressure inside the head to rise . This can put pressure on the brain and cause injury to the brain if it is not treated quickly . Typically , an extradural haematoma is caused by a severe head injury - for example , in a road traffic accident . The blood usually collects in the epidural space soon after a head injury and symptoms of an extradural haematoma are usually noticed quickly . So , most extradural haematomas are ' acute ' injuries . Occasionally , bleeding can occur more slowly and an extradural haematoma may cause few symptoms ( and so not be noticed ) until some days after a head injury . The rest of this leaflet just discusses intracranial extradural haematoma .,

natural_text: , surgery is generally needed to treat a large intracranial extradural haematoma . This is usually carried out by a neurosurgeon and involves removal of the haematoma . Most commonly , surgery either involves making ' burr holes ' in the skull or an operation called a craniotomy . Burr holes are small holes that are drilled through the skull over the area where the haematoma has formed . They allow the blood to be removed , or ' sucked out ' , through the holes . Stitches or staples are then used to close the burr holes . A craniotomy is a procedure in which a portion of the skull is removed so that the brain and meninges are exposed . It can relieve any raised pressure inside the skull and also means that the clotting blood in the extradural space can be removed . The section of skull that was removed is then replaced and fixed back in place , re - attaching the outer protective lining that covers the brain ( the dura mater ) to the skull bone . Close follow - up is needed after the operation , usually in an intensive care unit .,

Toxic to humans [ edit ]
The venom from the mosquito's bite can cause allergic reactions in humans. While most people may not experience significant symptoms, others can develop a severe allergic reaction known as anaphylaxis, which requires immediate medical attention.
Disease transmission [ edit ]
Anopheles mosquitoes are particularly deadly vectors for various diseases, including malaria in humans. In humans, they can transmit malaria parasites of the Plasmodium genus. They can also transmit other parasites and pathogens, such as viruses, bacteria, and filarial worms. Mosquitoes become infected with these diseases by feeding on infected hosts or by being in close proximity to infected hosts where the mosquitoes can acquire the pathogen through their biting apparatus.
Disease prevention [ edit ]
To reduce the risk of malaria and other mosquito-borne diseases, preventive measures include:
  1. Use mosquito nets or bed nets to cover sleeping areas, especially at night

In patients with IgA nephropathy, the IgA antibodies mistakenly attach to the kidney and start to damage the kidney tissue. This can then lead to protein leakage in the urine, blood or protein loss from the body. In some severe cases, IgA nephropy can cause kidney failure, where the kidneys are no longer able to filter waste and excess fluid from the blood effectively. Early detection and treatment of IgA nephro The main goal of treatment for IgA nephrotypathy is to reduce the inflammation in the kidneys and prevent further damage. How does it affect individuals with RHD?
Rheumatic fever often damages the valves between the chambers of the heart – specifically the mitral valve and the aortic valve. This damage can lead to the following effects:
Inability of the valve to close properly, causing blood to flow backwards – also known as backflow.
Incompetence of the valve, causing blood leaks and increases in pressure within the heart chambers.
Mitral stenosis, where the mitral valves get thickened and narrowed, restricting blood flow.
Aortic stenosis, where the aortic valves become narrowed, restricting the flow and causing the heart to work harder.
Other complications also arise, such as heart failure, arrhythmias (abnormal heartbeat), infective endocarditis (inflammation of the heart valves) etc. These effects can vary from being mild and manageable to severe and life-threatening. Some people might even need heart surgery.

Is mouth breathing bad for health?
Poor oral health, which often results in mouth breathing, has a negative impact on overall health. Mouth breathing may lead to problems like narrow dental arches, tongue thrusting, and temporomandibular joint disorders (TMJ disorders), which can further worsen oral health.

Effects of long-term mouth breathing include: Narrowed dental arches and an elongated or convex facial profile due to increased growth of the maxilla (upper jaw). Discrepancy in upper and lower tooth alignment, making it difficult to close the mouth properly.
Why is it important to stop mouth breathing?

In systemic sclerosis , the immune system damages the connective tissue cells , which are found in many parts of the body . Your connective tissue supports , binds or separates other tissues and organs within your body and can also be a kind of packing tissue in your body . So , systemic sclerosis is also classed as a connective tissue disease . It is not known what triggers the immune system to cause systemic sclerosis . There is probably an inherited tendency to develop it . It is more common in people who have a family member with systemic sclerosis . It may be triggered by certain germs ( such as viruses ) , medicines , street drugs and chemicals . A number of different influences seem to be involved . What is known is that cells called fibroblasts are affected by the immune system in some way and make too much of a protein called collagen . The collagen gets deposited in skin , blood vessels and organs . This causes scarring and thickening ( fibrosis ) . Blood vessels are also damaged .,

natural_text: Lymph glands ( also called lymph nodes ) occur throughout the body . They are normally pea - sized . They are a major part of the body 's defence ( immune ) system . During an infection , lymph glands swell and become painful while the immune system fights off infecting germs . They go back to normal after the infection is over . Most people are familiar with lymph glands in the neck that can swell when you have a sore throat or tonsillitis . In a similar way , it is the lymph glands in the tummy , next to the gut ( intestine ) , that swell during a bout of mesenteric adenitis . ( See separate leaflet called Swollen Lymph Glands for more about lymph glands . ) Probably , a germ ( infection ) triggers the inflammation and swelling in the lymph glands . Most cases are probably due to a viral infection . Less often , it may be a bacterial infection that is the cause - for example , a bacterial infection in the intestine . The inflamed glands then cause pain , tenderness and a high temperature ( fever ) .,

single medicine. Rhythm control means reverting the erratic heartbeat back to a normal regular rhythm. This is called cardioversion. One method of cardioversion is to give your heart a large electric shock, like in a paddling pool. This is known as direct current cardioversion or DC cardioversion. Alternatively, doctors can use a drug called Lignocaine to help convert the heart back into its natural rhythm. What is Insulin? Insulin is a hormone that plays a crucial role in regulating blood sugar levels in our body. It is produced by the pancreas, specifically in the beta cells of the islets of Langerhans. Insulin helps glucose enter the cells of the body from the bloodstream, where it can be used for energy or converted into glycogen for storage. In people with diabetes, either their pancreas does not produce enough insulin, or their cells are resistant to the insulin that is produced. As such, taking insulin regularly helps to regulate blood glucose levels.

In type 1 diabetes the body stops making insulin and the blood sugar level goes very high . Treatment to control the blood sugar level is with insulin injections and a healthy diet . Type 2 diabetes is the type which occurs mostly in people aged over 40 years but is becoming more common in younger adults and in children . Symptoms [ edit ]
Symptoms of Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome vary according to the type, but common symptoms include:
Gastrointestinal manifestations [ edit ]
Irritable bowel syndrome -like gastrointestinal symptoms, such as chronic constipation, diarrhea or both ( alternating constipation and diarrhea ) are common.
Joint hypermobility and dislocation [ edit ]
Excessive joint flexibility ( joint hypermobility ) can lead to frequent joint dislocations or subluxations. Instability of large joints, such as the knee or shoulder, is common in severe forms of the disease. People with EDS may have loose joints that can also pop or click.
Fragile skin [ edit ]
The skin of individuals with EDS is often described as fragile, which may lead to easily bruising, slow wound healing, and recurrent skin tears. Additionally, knuckle creases may appear on the hands, a trait often associated with EDS.

Haemochromosis is an inherited condition caused by a deficiency of the protein hemochromat in the intestine. This leads to excessive absorption of iron from the diet and buildup of iron in the body’s tissues, particularly the liver, heart and pancreas. Iron is normally absorbed in the small intestine and transported in the bloodstream bound to the protein transferrin. When there is too much iron, the body is unable to properly store and use it and it begins to accumulate in the tissues, leading to tissue damage and organ dysfunction.

Dermatitis means inflammation of the skin , and seborrhoeic means it affects the areas where there are sebaceous glands . These are the glands that make the oil ( sebum ) for the skin . The exact cause of seborrhoeic dermatitis is not known . It is thought that yeast germs from the Malassezia species may be involved . However , it is not just a simple skin infection and you can not catch this condition from others ( it is not contagious ) . The germs live in the sebum of human skin in most adults . In most people they do no harm . But some people may react to these yeast germs , making the skin become inflamed . People who have immune system problems , such as HIV and AIDS and people with Parkinson 's disease , are more likely to develop seborrhoeic dermatitis . Also , emotional stress is thought to aggravate the condition . Note : a lack of cleanliness does not cause seborrhoeic dermatitis .,

What is candidiasis? Candidiasis is a fungal infection caused by yeast called Candida. It often develops in warm, moist areas of the body such as the groin, armpits, and mouth. Symptoms include redness, itching, and the appearance of small white bumps or curved lines on the skin. Candidiasis can be caused by an overgrowth of yeast, a weakened immune system, antibiotic use, or wearing tight clothing. Treatment typically involves antifungal creams or powders. Preventative measures include practicing good hygiene, ensuring adequate ventilation, using antifungal powder, and avoiding excessive moisture. If symptoms persist, it is best to consult with a healthcare professional.

MS typically presents with a relapsing -remitting course, where symptoms come and go over time. NMO, on the other hand, often presents with a more acute and severe relapsing course. These then transmit the impulse to stimulate the contraction of the ventricular muscles. Conduction of electrical impulses through the heart is a rapid process that normally takes less than 0.2 seconds. The electrical activity of the heart is measured by an electrocardiogram ( ECG ), which records the electrical potential changes on the body surface. This record is called an electrocardio gram. The P wave indicates atrial depolarization. The PR interval indicates the time it takes for the impulse to travel from the atria to the ventricLES. The QRS interval indicates ventricular depolarization, and the T wave indicates ventricular repolarization ( Figure 3 ). If any part of the conduction pathway is'blocked'or severely damaged, it can lead to an abnormal
natural_text: . Most of the tissue between the atria and ventricles does not conduct the impulse . However , a thin band of conducting fibres called the atrioventricular bundle ( AV bundle ) acts like ' wires ' and carries the impulse from the AV node to the ventricles . The AV bundle splits into two - a right and a left branch . These then split into many tiny fibres ( the Purkinje system ) which conduct the electrical impulse throughout the ventricles . This makes the ventricles contract and pump blood through one - way valves into large arteries : The artery going from the right ventricle ( pulmonary artery ) takes blood to the lungs . The artery going from the left ventricle ( aorta ) takes blood to the rest of the body . The heart then rests for a short time ( diastole ) . Blood coming back to the heart from the large veins fills the atria during diastole : The veins coming into the left atria bring blood from the lungs ( full of oxygen ) . The veins coming into the right atria bring blood from the body ( needing oxygen ) .,
